text:
We can try to avoid the reality of trade-offs, but we can’t escape them.  

I once worked with an executive team that needed help with prioritization.  

They struggled to identify the top five projects for their IT department.  

One manager had a particularly hard time with it.  

She insisted on naming eighteen “top priority” projects.  

I insisted that she choose five.  

She took her list back to her team.  

Two weeks later, they returned with a shortened list.  

She had managed to shorten it by one single project!  

I always wondered what it was about that one project.  

By refusing to make trade-offs, she spread five projects’ worth of effort.  

She spread it across seventeen projects.  

Unsurprisingly, she did not get the results she wanted.  

Her logic had been: We can do it all.  

Obviously not.  

It is easy to see why it’s tempting to deny trade-offs.  

A trade-off involves two things we want.  

Do you want more pay or more vacation time?  

Do you want to finish this email or be on time for your meeting?  

Do you want it done faster or better?  

When faced with the choice, we prefer yes to both.  

But we cannot have it all.  

A Nonessentialist asks, “How can I do both?”  

Essentialists ask, “Which problem do I want?”  

An Essentialist makes trade-offs deliberately.  

She acts for herself instead of waiting to be acted upon.  

As economist Thomas Sowell wrote: “There are no solutions.  

There are only trade-offs.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Trade-offs are an unavoidable reality that require deliberate decision-making to prioritize effectively.
